bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge

div1.p: Robert Carter sends copies of letters he had sent earlier by the Prince to London merchant Robert Burridge concerning 5 hogsheads of tobacco shipped by the Carter consigned to Burridge's partner, Joseph Paice, and enclosing accounts of Burridge's affairs in his hands.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Robert Burridge, July 13, 1720

opener.dateline:
July 13th 1720.Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Mr. Robt Burridge

div1.p:
This accompan[ies] Coppys of my Lettr
& Accots by the Prince, James Wyatt Commandr. who
I hope is safe wth You long before now, I have now Shipt
upon Yor. Accot. 5 heavy hogsheads more tht net 4255 wth. cask in The Carter to Mr.
Joseph Paise Yor Partner, If the master will lett me
But Freit hath bin So plenty the Masr. hath refusd
Abundance of Tobo. That would not be Shipd to his ownrs.
If he should refuse bills of Lading for Yors To Paise I
Shall Send them to Mr. Wm. Dawkins Mercht. of London—
I have herein Sent You a Stated Accot. of all Yor. Concerns
There remains Due to You upon The Tobo. accot. 456
& upon yr. money Accot. £5"4/. There is outstanding
of Yor. Tobo. between 1500 & 2000 all to This balla[nce]. I
have answerd out of my own Tobo. The balla[nce]. of The
Money Accot. You must pay Yor. Self. I heartily Wish
You health & Prosperity & remain Sir

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 14-15.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence; the county and state were added for clarity.

[1] A vessel named the Carter traded to Virginia for many years; she is most often referred to as the Carter Frigatt. The captain in 1706 was Thomas Graves who is mentioned in the Lancaster County Court Orders Book for judgements against him obtained by RC. Later, the Carter would be commanded by Baily Kent, 1718-1721, Thomas Dove, and by Benjamin Graves. She was owned by RC and William Dawkins in 1720. (Survey report 6800 for Adm. 68/194-5, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; and Lancaster County Court Orders Book 5, 1702-13, p. 187, as abstracted in Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . . " )
